I know this might sound like a big change, but after 18 months of therapy and recovery work, I understand that I need some physical distance to maintain the boundaries I'm learning. The drinking was partly about coping with family stress, but also my own issues I'm continuing to work on.

Has anyone else moved cities while working on family boundaries in recovery? How did you maintain connections while protecting your sobriety? I'm excited but also nervous about balancing everything. My therapist reminds me it's normal to have mixed feelings about big changes, even positive ones.
red_flag_response:
Rating: 8.5/10

Why I’m rating it high:
- Protecting sobriety comes first. At 18 months, you’ve built real momentum, and your family’s comments and minimization are clear triggers. Going no-contact can be a strong boundary when prior attempts have failed.
- You have a concrete plan: a job prospect with solid pay, lease timing, savings, and a clean-slate strategy. That’s thoughtful, not impulsive.
- You’ve sought support and input (sponsor, groups, counselor recommendations). You’re not acting in isolation.

Why it’s not a 10:
- $12k is a decent cushion, but Denver’s cost of living is high. Make sure you’ve got first/last month rent, moving costs, deposit, and a 3–6 month emergency buffer planned out.
- No-contact is powerful, but irreversible steps (changing number immediately) can add stress during a move and new job transition. A staged boundary approach (blocked/muted, limited contact) for 30–60 days while you settle could reduce pressure, unless safety/relapse risk says otherwise.
- “Everything fits perfectly” can be a sign of all-or-nothing thinking. Even when families are toxic, staying anchored in your recovery tools (sponsor, therapist) helps prevent black-and-white narratives from driving decisions.

Suggestions to lock it in:
- Run a detailed budget for Denver (rent, deposits, commute, health insurance, groceries, recovery meetings). Pad with a contingency.
- Line up local supports before arrival: meetings schedule, a therapist or counselor, and at least one sober buddy in Denver.
- Draft a relapse-prevention plan specific to moving stress and loneliness.
- Consider sending the email only after you’ve secured the job and housing. If you still want full NC, do it once you’re stable.
- Journal your reasons for NC and the incidents that led here. When doubt/trauma-bonding hits, you’ll have your own record to ground you.

Bottom line: Your plan strongly aligns with protecting your recovery, and you’re taking thoughtful steps. Tighten the logistics and support network, then go.

red_flag_response:
Rating: 3/10

Why:
- Timeline risk: Four months is very fast to combine finances and housing, especially when stress-testing a relationship hasn’t happened yet. Cohabiting accelerates entanglement and makes breakups expensive/logistically messy.
- Financial red flags: You fronting a $3,600 deposit “until his invoice clears,” plus having already lent him money last month, shifts risk onto you. Consulting income variability plus “48 hours to move out” from his roommate are both yellow-to-red flags. Your $9k savings could be largely tied up in someone else’s cash-flow issues.
- Power/imbalance: He’s at your place most nights, knows “better taste,” picks restaurants/wine—none of that is bad, but paired with you funding key moments, it can create a dynamic where you shoulder the practical risk while he steers the vibe.
- Opportunity cost: You can likely find a place or arrangement that reduces your costs without legally binding you with a partner you’ve known for a short time.

If you still want to proceed, here’s how to de-risk:
- Don’t wire the deposit alone. Require him to transfer his half to you first or pay the landlord directly. No exceptions.
- Run a basic diligence checklist: verify his income (contract, payment schedule, 1099/W-2), credit check, and discuss debt. If this feels awkward, you’re not ready to co-lease.
- Get a cohabitation agreement: spell out who pays what, how to unwind, who keeps furniture, and how to handle early lease breaks.
- Keep separate finances for at least 6–12 months. Use a shared expense app or joint bill-pay account with capped deposits.
- Have an exit plan: can each of you cover the rent solo for 2–3 months? If not, don’t sign.
- Consider a trial: month-to-month sublet or him officially moving into your current place with a short written agreement before taking on a new 12-month lease.
- Protect your savings: keep a minimum emergency fund of 3–6 months living expenses untouched.

On decorating:
- Set a budget and split categories: you pick bedroom/bath, he picks dining, and collaborate on living room. Create a shared mood board and agree on 3–4 anchor items before buying anything else.
- Buy big items jointly only if you’ve agreed who keeps what (and how to value it) if you split.
- Start neutral on big pieces; add personality with art/textiles you each choose.

Bottom line: the relationship might be great, but the specific decision to wire the deposit and jump into a co-lease right now—with you floating cash—scores low. Slow the financial merge, verify income, and structure protections first.
reasonable_response:
Rating: 8.5/10

Why it’s strong:
- Timeline and compatibility: 14 months with 4–5 nights/week together and a full-month trial run is a solid gauge of day-to-day compatibility.
- Financial prudence: Transparent finances, separate emergency funds, and a written roommate-style agreement are excellent safeguards. Splitting a 2BR and saving $400/month strengthens your position.
- Planning buffer: Lease starts in February with a January live-in test gives you built-in checkpoints to adjust or back out.
- Communication: You’ve already had conversations about money, goals, chores, and guests—most couples skip these and suffer later.

What would move it closer to a 10:
- Exit plan in writing: Decide in advance how you’d handle a breakup or one person needing to move out mid-lease (who stays, notice period, financial responsibility for remaining rent, furniture division).
- Legal/financial logistics: Clarify whose name(s) are on the lease, how utilities are set up, and whether you need renters insurance with both listed. Consider a joint “household expenses” account with agreed monthly contributions, while keeping personal accounts separate.
- Conflict plan: Agree on a process for disagreements (e.g., weekly check-ins, a 24-hour cool-off rule, how to handle guests/family staying over, quiet hours).
- Long-term alignment: You’ve discussed goals—great. Make sure you’re on the same page about timelines for engagement/marriage, kids/no kids, and geography/career moves so cohabitation supports—not delays—those plans.

Decorating tips:
- Make a shared mood board first to align on color palette and vibe (e.g., warm modern, mid-century, cozy minimalist).
- Anchor pieces: Agree on the sofa, bed, and rug together—these set the tone. Let each of you “own” a zone (e.g., he curates the living room art wall, you curate the bedroom textiles).
- 70/30 rule: Keep 70% neutral/base, 30% personality accents so it feels cohesive but not generic.
- Storage and declutter date: Before moving, each commit to editing your stuff. Measure key pieces and map the layout to avoid duplicates.
- Buy slowly: Live in the space 1–2 months before buying lots of decor; the way you use rooms will inform choices.

Bottom line: You’re approaching cohabitation with uncommon thoughtfulness and financial clarity. Lock in the exit/contingency details and you’re in excellent shape.

red_flag_response:
My clear ranking: 3/10.

Why:
- Timeline and trust risks: 4 months + wiring a large deposit to a partner you don’t fully know yet (and who has credit/ID-theft issues) is a high-risk move. “Too smooth,” daily texts, and ring talk can be love-bombing, which can cloud judgment.
- Financial exposure: Sending $3,500, quitting before securing a job, and moving to a high-cost city will burn runway fast. Your $18k can evaporate quickly with move costs, deposits, furnishing, and months of job search.
- Power imbalance: You’d be financially dependent on him and his network in a new city, with no local safety net. If things go sideways, you’re vulnerable.
- Work situation: A bad review might be a catalyst, but reacting by quitting without another offer reduces leverage. It’s usually better to job-hunt while employed.
- Apartment urgency: “We have to move fast” plus “it won’t last long” is classic urgency pressure. Combined with him handling the lease due to his credit issues, that’s a red flag.

If you still want to pursue this:
- Don’t wire money directly to him. Pay the property manager/landlord through a verifiable portal and get your name on the lease.
- Verify everything: lease terms, landlord identity, unit availability, his ID theft claim (e.g., credit freeze confirmations), and the apartment listing independently.
- Secure your own runway: Aim for at least 6–9 months of living expenses post-move. Budget Portland costs realistically.
- Job first if possible: Apply now, schedule interviews remotely, or negotiate a delayed start at your current job while you search. Even a temporary remote or contract role helps.
- Housing safety: Consider a short-term sublet or month-to-month on your own for the first 2–3 months so you can acclimate and date locally without entangling finances.
- Boundaries: Slow the engagement talk. See how conflict, stress, and day-to-day compatibility feel in the same city before co-signing or cohabiting.
- Contingency plan: Separate bank account, return ticket or reserve, trusted friend in Portland, and a written exit plan if the relationship or job search stalls.

Big risks for love can be worth it, but the way you structure the risk matters. Reduce the irreversible steps (wiring money, quitting, co-signing) until your employment and relationship are more established.
reasonable_response:
I’d give your decision a 9/10.

Why not a 10? Because any cross-country move and cohabitation carries inherent uncertainty. But you’ve de-risked this exceptionally well. Here’s why it scores so high:

- Strong practical foundation: 20% salary increase, 6-week runway, $18k savings with a $5k move budget, and a clear emergency fund.
- Thoughtful relationship signals: 18 months together with 6 months LDR, consistent visits and cost-splitting, collaborative problem-solving (his spreadsheet, helping with negotiations), and keeping finances separate for a year.
- Career continuity: Solid job lined up, warm intros in your field, and an active professional contingency plan.
- Social and lifestyle planning: Hiking group already lined up, company with good reviews, and family support after meeting him.
- Risk mitigation: Clear exit ramps (sublet option, network maintained), therapist-vetted plan.

To push it to a 10:
- Formalize expectations: Have a cohabitation “operating agreement” (how rent/bills are split, chore cadence, guest policies, conflict process, plan if you break up and one needs to move).
- Add logistical safety nets: Put both names on the lease; clarify deposit return rules; document big shared purchases; keep your own credit and utilities history active.
- Timed checkpoints: Schedule 30-, 90-, and 180-day check-ins on relationship, finances, and city fit.
- Build local support: Line up a PCP/dentist, identify a therapist in-network in Portland, and set two recurring social commitments (meetup + hobby).

Neighborhood quick hits (assuming you want access to outdoors + good transit):
- Sellwood-Moreland or Woodstock: Leafy, calmer, great access to trails, solid cafes.
- Irvington/Alberta/Concordia: Charming older homes, artsy vibe, good food.
- Hawthorne/Division: Walkable, lively, lots of eateries; can be pricier and busier.

Bottom line: You’re choosing happiness with smart safeguards. That’s an excellent bet.

red_flag_response:
Rating: 4/10

Why not higher:
- Boundary and safety flags: Finding non-prescribed pills and “fighting about it” is a serious boundary breach and a clinical red flag, especially with opioids. Your clinical experience helps you empathize, but it can also blur lines—you’re not his provider, and moving in risks sliding into covert medication management or monitoring that’s not appropriate in a relationship.
- Caretaker dynamic risk: Moving in during a health crisis can lock you into a caretaker role before the relationship structure is fully tested. It can create power imbalances, resentment, or enablement—particularly around pain meds.
- Rationalization and minimization: “He’s not an addict” + “I overreacted” + “I can help taper him” reads as minimization. Tapering and pain management should be led by his prescriber/pain specialist, not a partner, even one who’s a nurse.
- Stress test pending: You’re 14 months in and excited—that’s great—but you haven’t resolved the medication trust issue. Cohabitation amplifies unresolved problems.

Why not lower:
- Strong relationship positives: Shared values/traditions, supportive family, practical upsides (timing, cost, space for your cat), thoughtful gestures, and PT progress. Those are meaningful green lights.
- Your insight and empathy: You’re self-aware about not wanting to be overbearing, and you understand the system’s shortcomings.

If you proceed, make it safer:
- Non-negotiables before moving in:
  - A signed pain-management plan with his prescriber/pain specialist, including transparent medication monitoring by the clinician, not you.
  - Agreement on no non-prescribed substances. If relapse occurs, predetermined steps (tell doctor, consider MAT, counseling).
  - Couples conversation on boundaries: you won’t be his nurse; you’re his partner. No covert pill counts or tapering plans by you.
  - Financial/lease clarity: Put terms in writing (rent split, utilities, exit plan if cohabitation doesn’t work).
  - Personal safety/exit plan: Keep your own savings, transportation, and a place you could go if things deteriorate.

- Build support:
  - He engages in PT consistently, plus behavioral pain strategies (CBT for pain, mindfulness, pacing).
  - Consider couples counseling to set caretaker-role boundaries.
  - Involve his family appropriately without triangulating you as the medical manager.

- Trial period:
  - Consider a 3–4 month trial with explicit check-ins at 30/60/90 days to reassess meds adherence, pain plan compliance, and relationship dynamics.

Bottom line:
You have a lot going for you two, but the medication breach and caretaker risk make immediate cohabitation during an active recovery phase risky. Shore up medical, behavioral, and boundary safeguards first; if he’s fully on board and follows through, your rating could move to a 7–8/10. As it stands today: 4/10.

If you still want to proceed, put structure around it:
- Timeline: Do a 3–6 month trial with a clear reevaluation date. Keep your current job until you’ve had at least 6–12 months of stability together.
- Written agreement: Draft a cohabitation agreement covering:

- Conflict norms: Agree on how you argue, cool-off rules, no name-calling/stonewalling. Gifts are not substitutes for accountability.

- Money: exact monthly contributions, what happens if one of you earns less one month, transparency expectations.
- Household: cleanliness standards, division of chores, quiet hours, shared calendar.
- Guests and overnights: friends, family, exes, frequency, notice.
- Privacy: phone/computer boundaries, alone time, working-from-home etiquette.
- Conflict: how you repair; therapy openness if needed.
- Long-term expectations: exclusivity, timeline for meeting family, holidays, marriage/kids stance.
- Dealbreakers: lateness, substance use, pets, travel, sex, finances.

- Support structure: Manager support, family support, and local colleagues lessen isolation and career risk.
- Intentionality: Pre-discussed finances, expectations, and starting couples counseling show great foresight.
- Fit with lifestyle: You’ve vetted the city’s community and hobbies, not just the relationship.

Why not a 10:
- You’ll still face the unknown of transitioning from LDR to day-to-day life together; even well-matched couples can discover friction in routines.
- You haven’t yet lived in the same city without training wheels; there’s always adjustment risk.

Suggestions to maintain independence:
- Set a personal routine early (your own gym, hobby nights, and friend group).
- Keep your own financial accounts and budget; review shared expenses transparently.
- Schedule solo time and individual trips back home or elsewhere.
- Define boundaries on frequency of overnights, keys, and expectations during the 6-month period.
- Keep therapy individual alongside couples counseling if feasible.

Cat move tips:
- Ask your vet about a mild anxiolytic or gabapentin for travel day if your cat gets stressed.
- Use a hard-sided carrier, familiar blanket, and Feliway spray.
- On arrival, start with a “base camp” room containing litter, food, water, scratcher, and favorite items; expand territory gradually.
- Keep the same litter and food initially; introduce new setups slowly.
- Maintain feeding/play schedules; high vertical spaces and hiding spots reduce stress.
- Update microchip registration and tags; secure windows/screens.

Overall, you’ve de-risked this thoughtfully. Green light with sensible safeguards.

red_flag_response:
Score: 4/10

Why:
- Moving in together can make sense after 18 months, especially if you’re effectively cohabiting already. Supporting a partner through school is also a valid choice. Those are the positives.
- The major red flags are financial and boundary-related:
  - Adding him to your primary bank account before he’s employed, with noted “unexplained ATM withdrawals,” is high risk. If things go south, you’re legally and financially exposed, and getting funds back can be difficult.
  - He “gets defensive” about budgeting/planning. Cohabitation with one partner unemployed requires more transparency, not less.
  - Recent instability: eviction conflict, job loss, new schooling, and now moving in—stacking multiple stressors increases the likelihood of conflict and poor decisions.
  - Celebrating acceptance is fine, but coupled with cash withdrawals and weak money habits, it hints at misalignment in financial priorities.
- Family skepticism isn’t decisive, but outside perspective can sometimes catch what we overlook.

What I’d change to move this to 8–9/10:
- Do not add him to your main bank account. Instead:
  - Open a separate joint household account with limited funds for shared bills only. You transfer a set amount each month; both have view-only transparency.
  - Keep your primary accounts and credit cards separate.
- Create a written agreement:
  - Budget for rent, groceries, utilities, transportation, and his school costs.
  - Define a contribution plan while he’s in school (e.g., chores, part-time income targets, job-search milestones).
  - Set a review cadence (monthly check-in).
- Address the cash withdrawals now. Calmly ask for a clean slate: from today forward, all cash spends get logged in a notes app or shared spreadsheet. If that’s a dealbreaker for him, that’s your data.
- Set guardrails:
  - Spending limits without mutual check-in.
  - No new debt in your name for his expenses.
  - Timeline for job placement after welding school and a plan if placement lags.
- Put a renter’s agreement in writing (even a simple roommate-style doc): move-out terms, notice period, and what happens if the relationship ends. It protects both of you.
- Credit safety: freeze your credit or at least lock it with your bank apps; don’t co-sign loans.
- Welding school/job placement: generally solid demand if the program is reputable. Look for:
  - AWS accreditation, completion rates, and employer partnerships.
  - Placement rates within 3–6 months and median starting pay in your region.
  - Encourage him to get basic certs (e.g., SMAW, MIG, TIG) and a plan for OSHA 10/30.
  - Ask the school for a written placement report and talk to recent grads.

Bottom line: Moving in can be fine; commingling finances right now is the risky part. Keep love and support high, but put strong financial structures in place before Saturday.

Why it’s strong:
- Timing and stability: Three years together, lots of overnights already, families integrated, and a new job starting next month with savings and severance as buffer. That’s a solid foundation.
- Clear financial structure: Proportional contributions to a shared expenses account, separate personal accounts, a budget spreadsheet, and monthly check-ins. That’s best practice.
- Transparency and trust: You flagged an ATM withdrawal, he clarified immediately with receipts. Good sign for communication and accountability.
- Practicality: Avoiding double rent and moving in when a lease ends is financially smart.

What keeps it from a 10:
- Job transition risk still exists until the first paychecks land; a few small safeguards would reduce exposure.
- Moving in and restructuring finances at the same time can strain even solid couples—just make sure boundaries are crystal clear.

Suggestions to get closer to a 10:
- Put agreements in writing:
  - Define who’s on the lease, how deposits are handled, and how you’d unwind expenses if needed.
  - Document proportional split and what counts as “shared” vs “personal.”
- Build a joint emergency buffer: Aim for 3 months of joint expenses in the shared account; keep personal emergency funds separate.
- Set spend thresholds: Any shared purchase over $X requires a quick check-in.
- Protect credit/auto-pay: Use the joint account only for shared bills; keep personal cards and subscriptions separate.
- Insurance and beneficiaries: Update renters insurance with both of you listed; confirm health/beneficiary choices once his new job starts.
- Furnishing on a budget:
  - Prioritize high-use items (mattress, couch, desk chair) and buy quality once; thrift or Facebook Marketplace for accent furniture.
  - Use price trackers and outlet stores; look for floor models/open-box deals.
  - Set a “furnish fund” with a capped monthly amount to avoid overspending.
  - Sell duplicates to offset costs.

Overall, your plan shows maturity, communication, and financial thoughtfulness. A couple of formal safeguards would make it nearly bulletproof.

Why:
- Meeting an ex at your home, especially while he’s mid-divorce, is a high-risk setting emotionally and practically. Privacy + history = easy to blur boundaries and rush intimacy before clarity.
- He may be doing real work, but you don’t have enough longitudinal proof that changes are stable outside of crisis. Early “growth” can be sincere and still not durable.
- You’re hiding it from friends. Secrecy is a red flag that your gut knows this could be messy. If you can’t say it out loud to your support system, pause.
- He moved fast into marriage and is now exiting just as fast. Pattern suggests difficulty tolerating discomfort/loneliness and making measured decisions.

What I’d do instead (if you want to explore this):
- Meet in public, daylight, one hour, clear boundary: this is a catch-up, not a reunion.
- No physical intimacy or “getting back together” talk for at least a few meetings. Watch actions over time.
- Ask direct questions: why marry the rebound? What did he specifically learn? What will he do differently when conflict hits? What are his separation/divorce timelines?
- Loop in one trusted friend for accountability.
- Set a check-in with yourself after: journal how you felt during/after, any pressure, any inconsistencies.
- If things proceed, wait until the divorce is finalized and he’s had some time single before exclusivity.

Saying yes to him bringing coffee to your place right now: not crazy, but unwise. Say yes to a public coffee; say no to home. That shifts this from a 4/10 to a 7/10 decision.

Why not a 10:
- The original issues—life goals and communication—aren’t trivial. Communication can improve with therapy; life-goal incompatibilities may not. You should explicitly revisit the life-goals piece if any reconnection is contemplated.
- Emotional risk: Even with boundaries, seeing an ex can reopen feelings. It’s manageable but real.

How to maximize the 8:
- Set an internal goal for the coffee (e.g., closure and information-gathering, not decision-making).
- Define boundaries beforehand: no “future talk” beyond clarifying goals unless you want it; keep it to one hour; no physical affection.
- Prepare a couple of key questions:
  - What specifically did you learn about your communication patterns, and how do you practice differently now?
  - Our life-goal mismatch was X—how do you see that today?
  - What, if anything, would make reconnecting a bad idea for us?
- Post-coffee plan: give yourself 24–48 hours before making any decision; debrief with your therapist/friend.

Bottom line: Saying yes to coffee in this context is reasonable and grounded. It’s not crazy—it’s cautious, intentional, and reversible.
